bibl.title: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to His Excellency, The Minister of Public Works, April 20, 1948

div1.p: Hench explains his discovery of the remains of Camp Lazear and his desire to honor Finlay and the American yellow fever commission by memorializing the site. He describes his plans for developing the site into a museum, park, and health clinic. Hench expresses appreciation for the Cuban appropriation of funds for the project, and offers $1000 for the immediate preservation of Building No. 1.

div1.head: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to His Excellency, The Minister of Public Works, April 20, 1948
div1.opener:
DR. PHILIP S. HENCH
MAYO CLINIC
ROCHESTER, MINN.
April 20, 1948
His Excellency
The Minister of Public Works
Republic of Cuba
Habana, Cuba
Your Excellency:
div1.p:
Last month (on March 10) Dr. Felipe Carbonell and Senor Honorato
Colete brought me to your office to meet you. Unfortunately I was unable to
get an appointment to see you but we discussed with your secretary a plan for
the preservation of “Camp Lazear” and the caseta (Major Walter Reed's
“Building Number One”) which still remains adjacent to the Macia-Zunqunegui
quarries behind the Finca San Jose in Quemados. It was at Camp Lazear and in
this caseta that Reed and his colleagues proved the mosquito theory of your
illustrious countryman, Dr. Carlos Finlay.

Camp Lazear was “lost” for 40 years until Mr. John Moran, Mr. Pogolotti
(both of Havana) and I hunted for it and found it in 1940. Since then it has
been my sincere hope that we could preserve the caseta and memorialize Camp
Lazear by erecting a small Cuban-American memorial. In 1900 Camp Lazear was
a part of the Finca San Jose. It is particularly appropriate to memorialize
this spot because it was also at the Finca San Jose (in the Quinta) that
Doctor Finlay himself performed a few of his earliest mosquito inoculations
in 1883.

I have been unhappy to find that in certain American circles not
enough is known about the pioneering work of Doctor Finlay, and in certain
Cuban circles not enough is known of the work of the United States Army
Board. I have noted an unfortunate attitude between those who would give
all the credit to the Americans and those who would give all the credit to
Doctor Finlay. In this magnificent medical achievement, so beneficial to
all mankind, there is surely sufficient glory for all who, united in a common
cause, constituted one of the greatest “teams” in all medical history. With
this in mind, it seems most appropriate to memorialize the services of all
concerned. Thus the unfortunate debate as to the relative merits of one or
the other group will be forgotten.

My original plan was very modest. I had hoped to raise certain funds
among American friends so that the caseta could be preserved on the spot within
a little Cuban-American Medical Memorial in which would also be kept originals
or copies of many souvenirs which I have, concerning the conquest of yellow
fever. Before the war the Mayo Clinic promised me a sum up to $10,000 contingent
upon the gifts of others and upon the assumption that the Cuban Government would
accept the gifts and care for the memorial. I had planned to raise about
$35,000. Then came the war; I entered military service and had to abandon
His Excellency, The Minister of Public Works
-2-
April 20, 1948
my plans temporarily.

During and since the war, I have had brief correspondence with
certain interested Cuban physicians, Doctors Presno, Nogueira and Carbonell
but could do nothing directly. I was delighted to hear that last year
the Cuban Government designated the caseta a “National Monument”. But no
funds were available for its preservation.

On my recent trip to Havana, I discussed the matter at some length
with Doctors Carbonell, Nogueira and Presno and with Senor Colete. Through
the courtesy of Doctor Carbonell, I also had the privilege of discussing it
with His Excellency, Vice President Paul de Cardenas. All of these gentlemen
appeared to be in hearty approval.

Fearing that the caseta might deteriorate even more seriously or might
even be destroyed (as was “Building Number Two” in the tornado of 1926) I asked
Senor Adrian Macia, owner of the property upon which the caseta stands, to erect
at my expense, a protecting galvanized iron cover around and over the caseta.
Thus the caseta would be protected while plans for its proper preservation were
proceeding. But because the caseta is now a “National Monument” Senor Macia
told me that I could not do this at my own expense without government permission.
It was then that we visited Vice President Cardenas, and I repeated my offer, but
he stated his belief that the caseta would be properly cared for while plans
were materializing.

Doctor Carbonell and I then discussed another plan with Senor Cardenas.
It would assuredly be better if the Cuban-American Memorial could be useful as
well as ornamental. We discussed the possibility of erecting not just a little
“museum-building” around the caseta, but a somewhat larger building to be used
as a small dispensario or unit for the Public Health Department of Quemados de
Marianao. In this case the caseta would be housed in a “museum-room” which would
be part of a Public Health unit.

The remains of Camp Lazear are surrounded by small homes for humble work-
ing people. It would indeed be fine if our memorial could serve these people in a
truly useful way.

Since my return home I have been delighted to learn that your depart-
ment has asked for, and (I understand) been authorized to expend $50,000 for the
preservation of the caseta, etc. Your Excellency, in writing you I do not wish
to intrude unduly in this matter but I do wish to express to you directly my
continuing great personal interest in this project and my desire to serve you
and my Cuban friends in any way I can.

I have given some thought to the manner of the memorial and enclose
herewith some rough sketches which illustrate my preliminary ideas.
Item 1 shows the caseta, “Building Number One”, as it now stands.
Item 2 shows an air-view (a photostat of a photograph; I regret
that I have no clearer view) of the remains of Camp Lazear in relation to the
Finca San Jose. The caseta is beneath the tree at (X). Reed's Building Number
Two was 80 yards in front of the caseta. Originally it had a wooden floor but
His Excellency, The Minister of Public Works
-3-
April 20, 1948
this rotted and Senor Zunzunegui put in a concrete floor. Since this building
blew down in 1926 the broken remains of the concrete floor mark the spot in the
corn field. (at X in the photograph).
Item 3 shows the location of Camp Lazear on the map of the Reparto
Pogolotti.
Item 4 shows my ideas regarding the preservation and beautification
of Camp Lazear. May I ask your consideration of the following ideas.
(a) Park: May I suggest that the corn field in front of the caseta
be purchased and made into a little park which (I should think) would be a
welcome addition to the working people living nearby. Entrance to the park
could be had merely by extending Calle Luis Valdes Carrero (or Calle Manuel
Gomez).
(b) The Caseta: could be protected by having it enclosed in a
“museum-room”. If it is not possible now to build a larger building (a small
unit to serve the people usefully in some manner such as would a health unit)
at least the “museum” could be erected now, being planned so as to harmonize
with later construction. Item 5 shows a rough sketch of the interior of the
museum or “museum room.”
The roadway leading from Calle Luis Valdes Carrero could enter the
little park through an ornamental gate-way, then approach the museum and health
unit by making a circle.
(c) Approximately in the center of the circle and where “Building
Number Two” (The “Mosquito Building”) stood could be erected an appropriate
memorial marker.
(d) Because the adjacent quarries make the land look somewhat un-
sightly the little park would look much nicer if a low stone wall surrounded
it. Perhaps the park will be beautified with trees and flower-beds. Here and
there in the park could be erected (perhaps against the wall) six or eight
stone seats something like those in the Prado.
(e) Naming the memorials. My suggestions along this line are merely
offered for your preliminary consideration. My desire is to honor all those
who joined in the conquest of yellow fever. May I suggest that the whole project
be known as the Cuban-American Memorial and that this name be on the gate-way.
The civic unit could be named the Finlay Building, the Finlay Health Unit or
the Finlay Health Clinic or some such designation. The museum or museum-room
housing the caseta could be named the Reed Memorial. The memorial marker in the
center of the park (on the former site of “Building Two”) could be small or large,
perhaps a simple marble or stone shaft bearing the names of all the participants
(Doctors Finlay, Delgado, Redd, Carroll, Agramonte and Lazear and Mezers. Moran
and Kissinger, Doctor Cooke and the 11 other American and Spanish volunteers.
If stone (or marble) seats are set up in the park and are of sufficient beauty
and dignity they could bear the names (simply out into the stone or on small
attached bronze markers) of certain distinguished persons who aided Finlay and
Reed, persons whose services were noteworthy, but of lesser value (such as
His Excellency, The Minister of Public Works
-4-
April 20, 1948
General Wood, Major Kean, Doctors Gorgas and Guiteras, Doctor Ames, and
Miss Clara Maass who died of experimental yellow fever).

Not to detract in any way from the sentiments implicit in my designa-
tion of the whole Project as the Cuban-American Memorial, may I suggest that
the little park itself be named “Parque Lazear”. This would perpetuate (in a new
version) the old historical designation “Camp Lazear”. You may recall that the
spot was named Camp Lazear to honor the memory of the heroic martyr, Dr. Jesse
W. Lazear, who died from what was, in all likelihood, deliberately accepted ex-
perimental yellow fever.

If it seems best to use only four names I suggest the museum (containing
the caseta) be called The Reed Museum, the civic unit be called “The Finlay Building”
the grounds be called “Lazear Park” and the designation of the whole project,
The Cuban-American Memorial, be placed at the entrance. The colleagues of
Finlay and of Reed can be duly honored by appropriate inscriptions on the
central marker and by data within the museum.

As to the material within the museum-room: I have much data- old and
new photographs of the places and persons concerned, original letters, old maps and
documents, original medical charts of the patients who developed experimental
yellow fever, etc., etc. I would be very glad to supply some originals and
some duplicates of these items to be placed in display cabinets, some on the
wall, some around the room. Copies or originals of data concerning Doctors
Finlay and Delgado should of course also be procured. It was my thought to
remove, of course, all parts which have been attached to Building Number One
which did not originally belong to it; two such additions have already been
removed; a rear addition (kitchen) remains. Enough of the rear wall of the
caseta could be removed (and the original wood used to restore the original
left front window) to allow visitors to look into the caseta from the rear.
The inside of the caseta should be restored to resemble its original appearance
with Army cots, boxes of “soiled linen”, an Army stove, etc. (These can be pro-
cured, I believe, from the U. S. Army).

Your Excellency, please accept these suggestions for what they are worth.
Undoubtedly you and your colleagues will have many ideas superior and more
practical than some of mine. Should you care to consult Mr. John Moran (one
of Major Reed's original volunteers for experimental yellow fever) about the
historical phases of the work, I am sure he would gladly cooperate (He lives
at Calle 25, No. 804, Entre B y C, Apartment Number 3, Vedado).
Doctors Carbonell and Nogueira are also quite familiar with many of these data;
they and Senor Macia would also cooperate fully, I am sure. They have been
most courteous and helpful to me.

I realize that to develop plans of sufficient dignity, beauty and
practicality will take some time. If there is any likelihood that the delay
in allotting funds and starting work may be dangerous for the “life” of the
caseta, may I express to you again my willingness to help meet the immediate
need to preserve the caseta from the hazards of hurricanes, weather, storm and
use, by making now a gift of $1,000.00 to enclose the caseta in a galvanized
iron cover.
His Excellency, The Minister of Public Works
April 20, 1948

Believe me, sir, it has given me great satisfaction to have had
a small part in the early phases of this venture. I have enjoyed greatly the
most pleasant contacts I have had with your countrymen. I shall be happy to
do anything I can to further the project and to serve the memories of those
we together choose to honor.
div1.closer: Sincerely, P. S. Hench, M.D. PSH:man
